prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this science goal, we will observe the 3(1,2)-2(2,1) and 2(1,1)-2(1,2) HDO transitions at 225.9 and 241.6 GHz. From our simplified estimates from the disk models described in the justification for the line peak flux, these are the strongest and best lines to observe in these sources and with the ALMA correlator it is possible to get both lines in one sideband each, at the same time. With FHWM of at least 1km/s, we can for the weaker detections smooth to 0.3 km/s channels, whereas for stronger sources we can use the requested channel width of 0.1 km/s to also probe the kinematics, however this is mainly a detection experiment.

To maximize our chances of detection we match the beam with the estimated size of the emitting region, this way the emission can be approximated to be distributed evenly over the beam. This is taken to be the region of the disk where T>100K. This is calculated from the isothermal passively heated thin disk model, i.e. T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. With these values, we get r(100K) = 22.5 AU, and at a distance of 140 pc the beam is choosen to cover the diameter of the region, i.e. 2*22.5/140=0.32 arcseconds. The total size of the water emitting region is taken to be less than 1 arcsecond in all cases.

We need a sensitivity of 4 mJy in 0.3 km/s bins to detect water in TMC1A at a 5 sigma level at line peak flux with the most conservative disk parameters of p>=0.6 E0>=0.14 g/cm^2 and Mdisk>=4E-04 Msun. The ortho-H2-18O abundances were estimated using an o/p-ratio of 3 and an 16O/18O-ratio of 550, appropriate for these environments Wilson & Rood (1994). The relative H2O gas-phase abundance was taken to be 9E-06, below current estimates (i.e. 2E-5 in IRAS 2A by Visser et al. 2013), and the HDO/H2O ratio is 6E-4 (D/H=3E-4), which makes it possible to detect the lines even when the HDO/H2O ratio is comparable to the low value of Solar System comets. This is also significantly lower than what was found toward Class 0 sources. For a FWHM>=1km/s we will detect the lines in >=3 bins, the resolution is set higher so for the sources with higher flux we can map the kinematics, however the main science goal is detection driven.
The continuum peak strength for TMC-1A is ~170 mJy at 1.3 mm (Harsono et al., 2014, Jorgensen et al., 2009). For L1489IRS it is 12 mJy at ~1.3 mm (Yen et al. 2014).
To calculate the *line* peak flux, we employ the isothermal passively heated disk model described in Harsono et al. (2014). The temperature falls off with radius as T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), with T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. The surface density: E=E0(r/r0)^(-p), with E0=surface density at r0=50 AU. The gas mass of the disk is then Mgas=2*pi*r0^(p)*E0/(2-p)*[r2^(2-p)-r1^(2-p)], taken between r1=r0 to r2=r(T=100K). Alternatively Mgas=Nmolecule*pi*r2^2*cos(i)*muH2*mp/Xmolecule, where Nmolecule=column density of molecule, r2=radius of disk region, i=inclination, muH2=mean molecular weight, mp=proton mass, and Xmolecule=relative abundance (respect to H2) of molecule. Nmolecule can be estimated from the integrated line flux (see e.g. Goldsmith & Langer, 1999) assuming optically thin emission and that it fills the beam uniformly. To get the line peak flux we assume a Gaussian line shape with a FWHM=1km/s, thus Fpeak = W/sqrt(pi*FWHM/(2*ln(2)^2)). The last figure in the scientific justification show the peak line flux for various "p" and "E0".

In this science goal, we will observe the 4(1,4)-3(2,1) ortho-H218O transition at 390.6~GHz (Band~8). From our simplified estimates from the disk models described in the justification for the line peak flux, this is the strongest and best line to observe in these sources and with the ALMA correlator it is possible to get both lines in one sideband each, at the same time. Since it is an ortho-H2-18O line, it is more abundant than e.g. the 322 GHz para line. With FHWM of at least 1km/s, we can for the weaker detections smooth to 0.3 km/s channels, whereas for stronger sources we can use the requested channel width of 0.1 km/s to also probe the kinematics, however this is mainly a detection experiment.

To maximize our chances of detection we match the beam with the estimated size of the emitting region, this way the emission can be approximated to be distributed evenly over the beam. This is taken to be the region of the disk where T>100K. This is calculated from the isothermal passively heated thin disk model, i.e. T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. With these values, we get r(100K) = 22.5 AU, and at a distance of 140 pc the beam is choosen to cover the diameter of the region, i.e. 2*22.5/140=0.32 arcseconds. The total size of the water emitting region is taken to be less than 1 arcsecond in all cases.

We need a sensitivity of 12.5 mJy in 0.3 km/s bins to detect water in TMC1A at a 5 sigma level at line peak flux with the most conservative disk parameters of p>=0.6 E0>=0.14 g/cm^2 and Mdisk>=4E-04 Msun. The ortho-H2-18O abundances were estimated using an o/p-ratio of 3 and an 16O/18O-ratio of 550, appropriate for these environments Wilson & Rood (1994). The relative H2O gas-phase abundance was taken to be 9E-06, below current estimates (i.e. 2E-5 in IRAS 2A by Visser et al. 2013), and the HDO/H2O ratio is 6E-4 (D/H=3E-4), which makes it possible to detect the lines even when the HDO/H2O ratio is comparable to the low value of Solar System comets. This is also significantly lower than what was found toward Class 0 sources. For a FWHM>=1km/s we will detect the lines in >=3 bins, the resolution is set higher so for the sources with higher flux we can map the kinematics, however the main science goal is detection driven.
The continuum peak line strength for TMC-1A is about 350 mJy scaled from 1.3 mm (Harsono et al., 2014). For L1489IRS it is ~60 mJy, also scaled from 1.3 mm (assuming beta~1).
To calculate the *line* peak flux, we employ the isothermal passively heated disk model described in Harsono et al. (2014). The temperature falls off with radius as T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), with T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. The surface density: E=E0(r/r0)^(-p), with E0=surface density at r0=50 AU. The gas mass of the disk is then Mgas=2*pi*r0^(p)*E0/(2-p)*[r2^(2-p)-r1^(2-p)], taken between r1=r0 to r2=r(T=100K). Alternatively Mgas=Nmolecule*pi*r2^2*cos(i)*muH2*mp/Xmolecule, where Nmolecule=column density of molecule, r2=radius of disk region, i=inclination, muH2=mean molecular weight, mp=proton mass, and Xmolecule=relative abundance (respect to H2) of molecule. Nmolecule can be estimated from the integrated line flux (see e.g. Goldsmith & Langer, 1999) assuming optically thin emission and that it fills the beam uniformly. To get the line peak flux we assume a Gaussian line shape with a FWHM=1km/s, thus Fpeak = W/sqrt(pi*FWHM/(2*ln(2)^2)). The last figure in the scientific justification show the peak line flux for various "p" and "E0".

In this science goal, we will observe the 3(1,2)-2(2,1) and 2(1,1)-2(1,2) HDO transitions at 225.9 and 241.6 GHz. From our simplified estimates from the disk models described in the justification for the line peak flux, these are the strongest and best lines to observe in these sources and with the ALMA correlator it is possible to get both lines in one sideband each, at the same time. With FHWM of at least 1km/s, we can for the weaker detections smooth to 0.3 km/s channels, whereas for stronger sources we can use the requested channel width of 0.1 km/s to also probe the kinematics, however this is mainly a detection experiment.

To maximize our chances of detection we match the beam with the estimated size of the emitting region, this way the emission can be approximated to be distributed evenly over the beam. This is taken to be the region of the disk where T>100K. This is calculated from the isothermal passively heated thin disk model, i.e. T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. With these values, we get r(100K) = 22.5 AU, and at a distance of 140 pc the beam is choosen to cover the diameter of the region, i.e. 2*22.5/125=0.36 arcseconds (we are consistent with 0.32 arcseconds for the whole proposal). The total size of the water emitting region is taken to be less than 1 arcsecond in all cases.

We need a sensitivity of 4 mJy in 0.3 km/s bins to detect water in TMC1A at a 5 sigma level at line peak flux with the most conservative disk parameters of p>=0.6 E0>=0.14 g/cm^2 and Mdisk>=4E-04 Msun. The ortho-H2-18O abundances were estimated using an o/p-ratio of 3 and an 16O/18O-ratio of 550, appropriate for these environments Wilson & Rood (1994). The relative H2O gas-phase abundance was taken to be 9E-06, below current estimates (i.e. 2E-5 in IRAS 2A by Visser et al. 2013), and the HDO/H2O ratio is 6E-4 (D/H=3E-4), which makes it possible to detect the lines even when the HDO/H2O ratio is comparable to the low value of Solar System comets. This is also significantly lower than what was found toward Class 0 sources. For a FWHM>=1km/s we will detect the lines in >=3 bins, the resolution is set higher so for the sources with higher flux we can map the kinematics, however the main science goal is detection driven.
GSS30-IRS continuum is taken to be ~150 mJy, and ~125 mJy for Elias 29 at 225 GHz (Jorgensen et al., 2009, Lommen et al., 2008).
To calculate the *line* peak flux, we employ the isothermal passively heated disk model described in Harsono et al. (2014). The temperature falls off with radius as T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), with T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. The surface density: E=E0(r/r0)^(-p), with E0=surface density at r0=50 AU. The gas mass of the disk is then Mgas=2*pi*r0^(p)*E0/(2-p)*[r2^(2-p)-r1^(2-p)], taken between r1=r0 to r2=r(T=100K). Alternatively Mgas=Nmolecule*pi*r2^2*cos(i)*muH2*mp/Xmolecule, where Nmolecule=column density of molecule, r2=radius of relevant region, i=inclination, muH2=mean molecular weight, mp=proton mass, and Xmolecule=relative abundance (respect to H2) of molecule. Nmolecule can be estimated from the integrated line flux (see e.g. Goldsmith & Langer, 1999) assuming optically thin emission and that it fills the beam uniformly. To get the line peak flux we assume a Gaussian line shape with a FWHM=1km/s, thus Fpeak = W/sqrt(pi*FWHM/(2*ln(2)^2)). The last figure in the scientific justification show the peak line flux for various "p" and "E0".

In this science goal, we will observe the 4(1,4)-3(2,1) ortho-H218O transition at 390.6~GHz (Band~8). From our simplified estimates from the disk models described in the justification for the line peak flux, this is the strongest and best line to observe in these sources and with the ALMA correlator it is possible to get both lines in one sideband each, at the same time. Since it is an ortho-H2-18O line, it is more abundant than e.g. the 322 GHz para line. With FHWM of at least 1km/s, we can for the weaker detections smooth to 0.3 km/s channels, whereas for stronger sources we can use the requested channel width of 0.1 km/s to also probe the kinematics, however this is mainly a detection experiment.

To maximize our chances of detection we match the beam with the estimated size of the emitting region, this way the emission can be approximated to be distributed evenly over the beam. This is taken to be the region of the disk where T>100K. This is calculated from the isothermal passively heated thin disk model, i.e. T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. With these values, we get r(100K) = 22.5 AU, and at a distance of 125 pc the beam is choosen to roughly cover the diameter of the region, i.e. 2*22.5/125=0.36 arcseconds (we are consistent with 0.32 arcseconds for the whole proposal). The total size of the water emitting region is taken to be less than 1 arcsecond in all cases.

We need a sensitivity of 12.5 mJy in 0.3 km/s bins to detect water in TMC1A at a 5 sigma level at line peak flux with the most conservative disk parameters of p>=0.6 E0>=0.14 g/cm^2 and Mdisk>=4E-04 Msun. The ortho-H2-18O abundances were estimated using an o/p-ratio of 3 and an 16O/18O-ratio of 550, appropriate for these environments Wilson & Rood (1994). The relative H2O gas-phase abundance was taken to be 9E-06, below current estimates (i.e. 2E-5 in IRAS 2A by Visser et al. 2013), and the HDO/H2O ratio is 6E-4 (D/H=3E-4), which makes it possible to detect the lines even when the HDO/H2O ratio is comparable to the low value of Solar System comets. This is also significantly lower than what was found toward Class 0 sources. For a FWHM>=1km/s we will detect the lines in >=3 bins, the resolution is set higher so for the sources with higher flux we can map the kinematics, however the main science goal is detection driven.
GSS30-IRS continuum is taken to be ~300 mJy, and ~250 mJy for Elias 29 at 390 GHz (Jorgensen et al., 2009, Lommen et al., 2008).
To calculate the *line* peak flux, we employ the isothermal passively heated disk model described in Harsono et al. (2014). The temperature falls off with radius as T=T0(r/r0)^(-q), with T0=1500K (dust sublimation temperature), r0=0.1 AU, q=0.5. The surface density: E=E0(r/r0)^(-p), with E0=surface density at r0=50 AU. The gas mass of the disk is then Mgas=2*pi*r0^(p)*E0/(2-p)*[r2^(2-p)-r1^(2-p)], taken between r1=r0 to r2=r(T=100K). Alternatively Mgas=Nmolecule*pi*r2^2*cos(i)*muH2*mp/Xmolecule, where Nmolecule=column density of molecule, r2=radius of relevant region, i=inclination, muH2=mean molecular weight, mp=proton mass, and Xmolecule=relative abundance (respect to H2) of molecule. Nmolecule can be estimated from the integrated line flux (see e.g. Goldsmith & Langer, 1999) assuming optically thin emission and that it fills the beam uniformly. To get the line peak flux we assume a Gaussian line shape with a FWHM=1km/s, thus Fpeak = W/sqrt(pi*FWHM/(2*ln(2)^2)). The last figure in the scientific justification show the peak line flux for various "p" and "E0".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water plays an important role throughout the entire star formation process, from cores to disks. In the cold dense outer parts of the protostellar envelope, water is the main constituent of icy grain mantles. When the grains are heated above 100 K, water is released into the gas phase. Previously, we successfully observed warm water towards four deeply-embedded (Class 0) low-mass protostars. The observations show compact, narrow warm water lines on scales <150 AU, but its origin remains elusive (hot corino or disk) and the deduced HDO/H2O ratio is slightly higher than Solar System comets. The previously observed sources are all in the same evolutionary stage (Class 0). To understand the origin of the warm water emission, and determine its HDO/H2O ratio (deuteration), we propose to observe the two isotopologues HDO and ortho-H2-18O in bands 6 and 8 towards four Class I sources. These more evolved sources will make it possible to further investigate and constrain the origin and deuteration of the warm water emission and how the water trail is affected by the evolution of the protostellar system.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00448.S, Origin of warm water emission in low-mass protostars, Persson, M.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Astronomy, Heidelberg, University of
Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen, University of
